sect1.title: ContainerCmdletProvider
sect1.para: The ContainerCmdletProvider class derives from the ItemCmdletProvider class and adds the notion of a container item that may contain other items. Items in a container are considerd child items which gives rise to a parent-child relationship. HDF5 groups are the only container items supported in PSH5X.

sect2.para: Gets the HDF5 items and HDF5 child items in one or more specified locations.

The Get-ChildItem cmdlet gets the items in one or more specified locations. If the item is an HDF5 group, it gets the items inside the container, known as child items. You can use the Recurse parameter to get items in all child containers.

listitem.para: Specifies a path to one or more locations. Wildcards are permitted. The default location is the current directory (.).
Retrieves only the names of the items in the locations. If you pipe the output of this command to another command, only the item names are sent.
Gets the items in the specified locations and in all child items of the locations.
Recurse works only when the path points to a container that has child items, such as h5tmp:\ or h5tmp:\*, and not when it points to items that do not have child items.
Retrieve detailed information about each child item.

This parameter can be used to specify a filter on the types of items to be retrieved or to be suppressed. Filters are more efficient than other parameters, because the provider applies them when retrieving the objects, rather than having PowerShell filter the objects after they are retrieved.

The PSH5X item filter either includes items of the types listed (e.g., only groups and datasets) to the exclusion of all other item types, or it suppresses all items of types listed and includes all types not listed. The items type abbreviations are as follows: d - datasets e - external links g - groups s - soft links t - named datatypes For example, -Filter g retrieves only groups to the exclusion of all other item types, and -Filter -dg suppresses all datasets and groups.

example.title: Getting the children of the PSDrive with root h5tmp:\
example.screen:
PS:1 > Get-ChildItem h5tmp:\
PSParentPath: HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:
LinkName ItemType LastWriteTime #Attr. -------- -------- ------------- ------ dset1 Dataset 8/8/2011 4:07:21 PM 0 dset2 Dataset 8/8/2011 4:05:00 PM 0 dset3 Dataset 8/8/2011 4:05:00 PM 0 group1 Group 1/1/1970 12:00:00 AM 0 group2 Group 1/1/1970 12:00:00 AM 0 slink1 SoftLink type1 Datatyp... 1/1/1970 12:00:00 AM 0

example.title: Getting the children of the PSDrive with root h5tmp:\ using wildcards
example.screen:
PS:1 > Get-ChildItem h5tmp:\dset*
PSParentPath: HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:
LinkName ItemType LastWriteTime #Attr. -------- -------- ------------- ------ dset1 Dataset 8/8/2011 4:07:21 PM 0 dset2 Dataset 8/8/2011 4:05:00 PM 0 dset3 Dataset 8/8/2011 4:05:00 PM 0

example.title: Recursively getting the children of the PSDrive with root h5tmp:\
example.screen:
PS:1 > Get-ChildItem h5tmp:\ -Recurse | Sort-Object PSParentPath
PSParentPath: HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:
LinkName ItemType LastWriteTime #Attr. -------- -------- ------------- ------ group2 Group 1/1/1970 12:00:00 AM 0 slink1 SoftLink type1 Datatyp... 1/1/1970 12:00:00 AM 0 group1 Group 1/1/1970 12:00:00 AM 0 dset2 Dataset 8/24/2011 12:11:37 PM 0 dset1 Dataset 8/24/2011 12:11:37 PM 0 dset3 Dataset 8/24/2011 12:11:37 PM 0
PSParentPath: HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:\group1
LinkName ItemType LastWriteTime #Attr. -------- -------- ------------- ------ dset3 Dataset 8/24/2011 12:11:37 PM 0

example.title: Recursively getting the children of a PSDrive which are symbolic links or named datatypes
example.screen:
PS:1 > Get-ChildItem h5tmp:\ -Recurse -Filter st | Sort-Object PSParentPath
PSParentPath: HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:
LinkName ItemType LastWriteTime #Attr. -------- -------- ------------- ------ type1 Datatyp... 1/1/1970 12:00:00 AM 0 slink1 SoftLink

example.title: Recursively getting the children of a PSDrive which are not symbolic links or named datatypes
example.screen:
PS:1 > Get-ChildItem h5tmp:\ -Recurse -Filter -st | Sort-Object PSParentPath PSParentPath: HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:
LinkName ItemType LastWriteTime #Attr. -------- -------- ------------- ------ group1 Group 1/1/1970 12:00:00 AM 0 group2 Group 1/1/1970 12:00:00 AM 0 dset3 Dataset 8/24/2011 12:11:37 PM 0 dset1 Dataset 8/24/2011 12:11:37 PM 0 dset2 Dataset 8/24/2011 12:11:37 PM 0
PSParentPath: HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:\group1
LinkName ItemType LastWriteTime #Attr. -------- -------- ------------- ------ dset3 Dataset 8/24/2011 12:11:37 PM 0

sect2.para: Creates a new HDF5 item.

cmdsynopsis.arg:
-ItemType Dataset, Datatype, Group,
ExtLink, HardLink, Image, SoftLink

note.para: The release version of PSH5X will support HDF5 packet tables H5PT

sect2.para: The New-Item cmdlet creates a new item and sets its value (if applicable). The basic syntax of New-Item is shown. It consists of the new item's name, its item type, and its value. Depending on the item type additional options may be required and are shown separated by item type.

listitem.para: Specifies the name of the new item. You can use this parameter to specify the name of the new item, or include the name in the value of the Path parameter.
Specifies the path to the location of the new item. Wildcards are permitted.
You can specify the name of the new item in the Name parameter, or include it in the Path parameter.
Specifies the type of the new item.
Specifies the value of the new item.
Force the creation of intermediate groups.

sect3.title: HDF5 Dataset
sect3.para: One or more of the following options must be specified for creating a new HDF5 dataset. Currently, the -Value argument has no meaning for datasets.

listitem.para: Specifies the HDF5 datatype of the new dataset. This can be a string, containing a type abbreviation (see ) or HDF5 path name of a named datatype, or a hashtable with a full-fledged HDF5 datatype definition (see ).
Specifies the dimensions of the new HDF5 dataset. The length of the array is the rank of the dataspace.
Specifies the maximum extent of the new HDF5 dataset. The length of the array is the rank of the dataspace.
Specifies the chunk size of the new HDF5 dataset. The length of the array is the rank of the dataspace. This option is incompatible with the -Compact, -Scalar, and -Null parameters.
Specifies compact layout for the new HDF5 dataset. This option is incompatible with the -Chunked, -Scalar, and -Null parameters.

Specifies the compression level for the new HDF5 dataset. Currently only datasets with chunked layout support compression. This option is incompatible with the -Compact, -Scalar, and -Null parameters.

note.para: The -FillValue, -Null, and -Scalar parameters have not been implemented in the beta version of PSH5X.

sect3.title: HDF5 Datatype
sect3.para: The following options must be specified for creating a new named HDF5 datatype.

listitem.para: This can be a string, containing a type abbreviation (see ) or HDF5 path name of a named datatype, or a hashtable with a full-fledged HDF5 datatype definition (see ).

sect3.title: HDF5 Group
sect3.para: No additional options need to be specified for creating a new HDF5 group. The -Value argument has no meaning for groups.

sect3.title: HDF5 External Link
sect3.para: The -Value argument must be a string array of length two. The first element is used as the file name and the second must be a well-formed HDF5 path name.

sect3.title: HDF5 Hard Link
sect3.para: The -Value argument must be a string containing a valid HDF5 path name.

sect3.title: HDF5 Image
sect3.para: See HDF5_Image for the HDF5 Image and Palette specification.

If the -Value argument is specified, it is expected to be the name of an image file. All of the image characteristics (bits, width, height etc.) will be inferred and no other options need to be specified. Otherwise the following options must be specified for creating a new HDF5 image.

listitem.para: Specifies the color depth of the new HDF5 image. Currently, only 8- and 24-bit raster images are supported.
Specifies the width and height (in pixels) of the new HDF5 image.
Specifies the interlace mode of the new HDF5 image.

example.title: Creating an HDF5 image from a GIF image
example.screen:
PS:1 >New-Item h5tmp:\gif -ItemType Image -Value .\Pictures\polycrystal1.gif
PSParentPath: HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:
LinkName ItemType LastWriteTime #Attr. -------- -------- ------------- ------ gif Dataset 8/31/2011 9:24:35 PM 4
PS:2 >Get-Item h5tmp:\gif | Format-List
PSPath : HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:\gif PSParentPath : HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp: PSChildName : gif PSDrive : h5tmp PSProvider : HDF5\HDF5 PSIsContainer : False StorageSizeBytes : 492093 Rank : 2 MaxDimensions : {511, 963} Layout : Contiguous ExtentType : Simple ElementType : {SignType, BitOffset, Class, MSBitPadding...} ElementTypeClass : Integer ElementCount : 492093 Dimensions : {511, 963} Chunk : Timestamps : {ModificationTime, AccessTime, ChangeTime, BirthTime} AttributeNames : {CLASS, IMAGE_VERSION, IMAGE_SUBCLASS, PALETTE} AttributeCount : 4 ItemType : Dataset

sect3.title: HDF5 Soft Link
sect3.para: The -Value argument must be a string containing a well-formed HDF5 path name.

sect2.para: Deletes the specified HDF5 items.
The Remove-Item cmdlet deletes one or more HDF5 items.

listitem.para: Specifies a path to the items being removed. Wildcards are permitted.

sect2.para: Renames an HDF5 item in the PSH5X provider namespace.

The Rename-Item cmdlet changes the link name of a specified item. This cmdlet does not affect the content of the item being renamed. You cannot use Rename-Item to move an item, such as by specifying a path along with the new name. To move and rename an item, use the Move-Item cmdlet.

listitem.para: Specifies the path to the item to rename.

Specifies the new name of the item. Enter only a name, not a path and name. If you enter a path that is different from the path that is specified in the Path parameter, Rename-Item generates an error. To rename and move an item, use the Move-Item cmdlet. You cannot use wildcard characters in the value of NewName. To specify a name for multiple files, use the Replace operator in a regular expression.

sect2.para: Copies an HDF5 item from one location to another within a namespace.

The Copy-Item cmdlet copies an item from one location to another in a names pace. Copy-Item does not delete the items being copied. Use the -Force switch to force the creation of missing intermediate HDF5 groups.

listitem.para: Specifies the path to the items to copy.
Specifies the path to the location where the items are to be copied.
Preserves container objects during the copy operation.
Force the creation of missing intermediate HDF5 groups.

sect2.para: Gets information about the current working location.
The Get-Location cmdlet gets an object that represents the current directory, much like the pwd (print working directory) command.
When you move between PowerShell drives, PowerShell retains your location in each drive. You can use Get-Location to find your location in each drive.

listitem.para: This parameter is used to specify the path to a new working location.
This parameter is used to specify the path to a new working location.

example.title: Working with locations
example.screen:
PS:1 > Get-Location
Path ---- C:\
PS:2 > Set-Location h5tmp:\group1 PS:3 > Push-Location PS:4 > Set-Location D:\ PS:5 > Pop-Location PS:6 > Get-Location
Path ---- h5tmp:\group1

sect2.para: Sets the current working location to a specified location.
The Set-Location cmdlet sets the working location to a specified location. That location must be an item that is an HDF5 group.

listitem.para: This parameter is used to specify the path to a new working location.

example.title: Set the working location to h5tmp:\group2
example.screen:
PS:1 > Set-Location h5tmp:\group2; Get-ChildItem
PSParentPath: HDF5\HDF5::h5tmp:\group2
LinkName ItemType LastWriteTime #Attr. -------- -------- ------------- ------ dset3 Dataset 8/8/2011 4:05:00 PM 0

sect2.para: Adds the current location to the top of a list of locations (a "stack").

The Push-Location cmdlet adds ("pushes") the current location to the top of a list of locations, called a "stack." You can push the current location onto a default stack or onto a stack that you create. If you specify a path, Push-Location pushes the current location onto the stack and then changes the current location to the location specified by the path. You cannot push a location onto the stack unless it is the current location.

listitem.para: Changes your location to the location specified by this path after it adds (pushes) the current location onto the top of the stack. Enter a path to any location whose provider supports this cmdlet. Wildcards are permitted. The parameter name Path is optional.
Specifies the name of a stack. The current location is pushed onto this stack, and this stack becomes the current stack. If the stack does not yet exist, it is created.

sect2.para: Changes the current location to the location most recently pushed onto the stack. You can pop the location from the default stack or from a stack that you create by using the Push-Location cmdlet.

The Pop-Location cmdlet changes the current location to the location most recently pushed onto the stack by using the Push-Location cmdlet. You can pop a location from the default stack or from a stack that you create by using a Push-Location command.

listitem.para: Specifies an alternate stack. Pop-Location pops the most recently added location from this stack. This stack then becomes the current stack.

sect2.para: Resolves the wildcard characters in a path, and displays the path contents.
The Resolve-Path cmdlet interprets the wildcard characters in a path and displays the items and containers at the location specified by the path, such as the HDF5 datasets and groups.

listitem.para: Specifies the PowerShell path to resolve. This parameter is required.

example.title: Resolving a path
example.screen:
PS:1 > Resolve-Path h5tmp:\dset*
Path ---- h5tmp:\dset1 h5tmp:\dset2 h5tmp:\dset3

sect2.para: Determines whether all elements of a path exist.

The Test-Path cmdlet determines whether all elements of the path exist. It returns TRUE ($true) if all elements exist and FALSE ($false) if any are missing. It can also tell whether the path syntax is valid and whether the path leads to a container or a terminal (leaf) element.

listitem.para: Specifies a path to be tested. Wildcards are permitted. If the path includes spaces, enclose it in quotation marks.
Determines whether the syntax of the path is correct, regardless of whether the elements of the path exist. This parameter returns TRUE if the path syntax is valid and FALSE if it is not.
Tells whether the final element in the path is of a particular type. This parameter returns TRUE if the element is of the specified type and FALSE if it is not.

Valid values are:
Container
An element that contains other elements, i.e., an HDF5 group.
Leaf
An element that does not contain other elements, i.e., not an HDF5 group.
Any
Either a container or a leaf. Tells whether the final element in the path is of a particular type. Returns TRUE if the element is of the specified type and FALSE if it is not.

example.title: Testing paths
example.screen: PS:1 > Test-Path h5tmp:\dset* True PS:2 > Test-Path h5tmp:\dsett* False PS:3 > Test-Path h5tmp:\dset* -IsValid True PS:3 > Test-Path h5tmp:\dset* -PathType Container False
